fields.description:
I'll track each of these as subtasks:

- Reduce latency, particularly for all-repository searches.
- Wherever possible, include hit in displayed results. For example, searching for author's username displays rev ids, but nothing else.
- Allow search by authors' full names.
- Allow camel-case search of filenames.
- Include results from Crucible.
- Support slashes in filename searches.
- Improve weighting of recently modified files.
- Document keywords (e.g. filename:foo.txt cs:765765).

fields.description:
FishEye is currently unnecessarily conservative and pessimistic in managing concurrent access to Lucene indexes.

For example, while a Lucene index is being written to, all threads are prevented from reading the same index.

With recent releases of Lucene, this level of locking is unnecessary.  It should be removed to allow greater parallelism.
fields.summary: Remove unnecessary locking during access to Lucene indexes

fields.description:
> Do we indicate if the backup has been anonymized? Or is that something separate?

It gets printed as a warning to the console when you create the archive:

"Warning: this backup has been anonymised and should NOT be used as a backup. It does NOT contain your data."

But I agree that we should also add that to the archive meta data here.
In fact: I'll take a look to see if its possible/feasible to include the entire log/output in the archive (or otherwise at least all error/warning messages).
fields.summary: Add output/log to backup.zip

fields.description:
Sometimes customers want to use fisheye for the bare minimum (To allow fisheye-plugin in jira to work) and because they have large repositories. 

Thus they can disable indexing of content and set store diff info to "no", but fisheye will still scan files to determine line count. 

It would be good to have an option to disable line count, similar to disabling content indexing and storing diff info.
fields.summary: Add option to disable line count

fields.description: Because "built-in" is no longer part of the available db types (omitting a type implies built-in), it's no longer possible for Restore to distinguish between restoring an archive using the backup's config.xml, and restoring an archive that is configured to use an external db into built-in.

fields.description:
The problem was then when it was processing a particular label - i.e. needing more info on the label it would look though all labels and pick out the one that it was interested in.

This has been fixed to just query the given label - it still does not use the path (because you can't with a single label)
fields.summary: p4 calls labels command without supplying path when it needs to get the info on a particular label

fields.description:
Anyone who has re-indexed since 1.6 has noticed a very large increase in disk space requirements, as a consequence of FishEye's more comprehensive content searching capabilities.  Customers have been annoyed by the sudden, unexplained increase in disk space requirements, and the lack of guidance we provide on disk space dimensioning in general.  (See the parent issue)

I've been able to apply some tweaks that will reduce index sizes somewhat for all customers (~12%).  Customers will only see this benefit once they re-index after upgrading.

In addition, I've added a new per-repository setting "enable-hit-highlighting", which is enabled by default.  Customers may choose to reduce their index sizes further (~30%) by disabling this feature.  The customer must re-index the relevant repositories to realise the disk space saving.  Once they have done so, they will no longer see contextual "hit highlighting" in their search results.  This only affects the presentation of search results; it does not affect the set of results returned for any search query.

Unfortunately, it is impossible to provide customers with guidelines for accurately predicting their disk space requirements, as there are just too many variables:  Repository implementation, file sizes, content type, diff sizes, comment sizes, etc.  The best we can do is provide them with some guidance based on our own experience, and advise that their mileage may vary, and that they should monitor their FishEye instance's use of disk space.

I'm planning to make other indexing-related changes before 2.0.  Once they're done, I'll collect some indicative disk usage data for you to include as guidelines.
fields.summary: Document disk space usage changes

fields.description:

* REST 1.0.0.rc3
fields.summary: Upgrade to latest AGSL-1

fields.summary: FishEye Customization - Set the number of row in search result page

fields.description:
Hello

We are currently having our fisheye/crucible polling from a svn 1.3 repository. We are going to upgrade to svn 1.6 using the dump/load procedure. We'll change the repository uuid but won't change the name (to be sure this is clear... fisheye knows our repository as http://hoffman/svn/axs and we will keep this same url).

My question is, we'll shutdown fisheye/crucible, dump the current repo, load in a new repo (1.6) and start fisheye/crucible. Will fisheye/crucible seamless recognize the new repo?

Thanks,
Javier
fields.summary: fisheye on svn upgrade and repository change question

fields.description:
At our company, we want to easily be able to chart the amount of code churn that happens at any given time.  This tells us about the current stability of our code base.  The current mechanism available in FishEye is change in total line count.  What we really want to see is the total number of lines that were "touched".

There is a hack work around where the data is exported to CSV files and then pulling information out of them.  This is cumbersome and what we pull out is the sum of lines added + lines removed.  

In addition, we would really like it if there was a mechanism to  remove commented lines from this count.
fields.summary: Code churn stats

fields.description:
{quote}
Hello,

We have two use cases that we find hard with Fisheye.

1. We would like to be able to get a notion of the daily code churn.
2. We would like to be able to view change sets based on how much churn they have created.

In both these cases, we can extract this information using searches, however, this is far from perfect. The problems with this method are:
1. I have to manually add the lines add+removed and have to do that for every file within a change set.
2. I have to create a separate program that extracts this information.
3. After I have extracted the daily churn, I have to manually go through every change set and see which change sets have lots of changes and then go to that change set to get the information to send out.

Thanks,
Adam 
{quote}

From [http://forums.atlassian.com/thread.jspa?threadID=33804&tstart=0]
fields.summary: Getting Daily Code Churn

fields.description: Only keep the most recent lines in the scrolling backup log to prevent browser memory problems.

- 2.0 will officially support Safari 2+, FF3+ and IE7.

This is true for FE and CRU.

fields.summary: Update FE System Requirements - remove IE 6 from support browsers

fields.description:
According to the documentation at:

http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/FISHEYE/Servlet+Plugin+Module

If we add the attribute adminLevel="system" to our servlet plugin any requests should have to be authenticated as an admin in order to access it. We have exposed a RESTful API via a custom servlet (through Jersey) and it appears that security is NOT enforced across all request types. While GET request types seem to be enforced correctly, if you do a PUT request our service is called successfully without any authentication. This is a big security hole as update calls that should be protected will be accessible by anyone.
fields.summary: Servlet Plugin Security Not Enforced

fields.description:
If your svn info returns:

{noformat}
> svn info file:///Users/pkamal/sourceCode/cenqua/fisheye/trunk/repo/svn/test/blah/date
Path: date
URL: file:///Users/pkamal/sourceCode/cenqua/fisheye/trunk/repo/svn/test/blah/date
Repository Root: file:///Users/pkamal/sourceCode/cenqua/fisheye/trunk/repo/svn/test
Repository UUID: 3e472751-1830-4915-9563-8f61084b204e
Revision: 7
Node Kind: directory
Last Changed Author: pkamal
Last Changed Rev: 6
Last Changed Date: 2009-05-05 13:48:42 +1000 (Tue, 05 May 2009)
{noformat}

Where the last changed rev is before the revision where the move occured:

{noformat}
>svn log -v -r 6:HEAD file:///Users/pkamal/sourceCode/cenqua/fisheye/trunk/repo/svn/test/
------------------------------------------------------------------------
r6 | pkamal | 2009-05-05 13:48:42 +1000 (Tue, 05 May 2009) | 1 line
Changed paths:
   M /svnrepo/blah/date/trunk/file.txt

mod file
------------------------------------------------------------------------
r7 | pkamal | 2009-05-05 13:51:16 +1000 (Tue, 05 May 2009) | 1 line
Changed paths:
   A /blah (from /svnrepo/blah:6)
   D /svnrepo/blah

move dir
------------------------------------------------------------------------
{noformat}

Then if you define your repository to be 

svn_url = file:///Users/pkamal/sourceCode/cenqua/fisheye/trunk/repo/svn/test/
path = blah/date 

Then the repository will be blank, as the last changed rev is 6, which points to a path outside of the defined fisheye svn url.
fields.summary: Svn repository will show up as blank when the last changed rev (returned from svn info) is prior to a svn move
